thread.title: Performance reviews are on the way out but watch what you wish for
thread.title_full: Performance reviews are on the way out but watch what you wish for | afr.com

author: Patrick Durkin with James Thomson
title: Performance reviews are on the way out but watch what you wish for
text:
In the euphoric rush to discard your goal-setting plans, stop for a second to consider what comes next. by Patrick Durkin with James Thomson Reports of the death of the annual performance review sent social media into meltdown this week, as workers from around the world celebrated the end of our most-dreaded office ritual.
"What a great move!" Tweeted one.
"The death of the annual performance review can't come soon enough," wrote another after management consultancy group Accenture , then local companies National Australia Bank and Deloitte announced they were following companies such as SEEK in ditching the much maligned reviews.
And AFR Weekend understands Qantas is joining KPMG, Westpac and Fairfax Media (publisher of The Australian Financial Review ) in considering dropping the traditional management structure in favour of "ongoing feedback".
James Spenceley, CEO of Vocus Communications, is keen on outside-of-the-box thinking. Ben Rushton In fact, it was as if corporate Australia met this week and agreed to blow the whistle on human resources longest-running folly.
"What happens in big companies is that the process takes over, and it's all about the process and not the conversation," NAB chief executive Andrew Thorburn tells AFR Weekend , after deciding to put his 43,000 staff out of their misery.
Once the dam wall broke, years of pent up frustration about the flawed process was suddenly unleashed.
"Employees that do best in performance management systems tend to be the employees that are the most narcissistic and self-promoting," the HR practice leader for the Corporate Executive Board, Brian Kropp quipped, in a damning put-down of the annual review.

In the euphoric rush to discard your goal-setting plans and feedback matrixes, stop for a second to consider what comes next.
What does it mean for your next pay rise? How do companies deal with problematic employees? And what about companies that drop the annual performance review in favour of â€¦ nothing. Or worse still, constant and endless feedback!
"I think performance reviews should happen daily, like a constant feedback loop," Thorburn says. "To me it's conversations every day, and not twice a year."
Newest tech-savvy tools being flogged Human resources experts and consultants are already out in force, offering businesses a host of new tech-saavy, online and instant feedback tools that might have us pining for the good old days.
According to the experts, the workplace of the future involves each of us constantly assessing and reviewing each other at work using social networks, such as the "skill endorsement" button on LinkedIn, Facebook's "thumbs up" and "thumbs down", emojis or possibly even swiping left or right about your colleagues like the dating app Tinder.
HR apps are flourishing such as JobVibe and the recently ASX-listed REFFIND , which has signed up companies including Coca-Cola, Lion Nathan and Coles and allows businesses to send employees feedback questions, issue short training videos or send company-wide memos on a "Tinder-style" interface.
"A lot of clients are moving to technology solutions where you can effectively tweet feedback on a regular basis," head of PwC's People Business John Williams says.
"The thing that triggered this for me was last year when I went through Heathrow airport and they have a little iPad on a stand that asks 'how was your security experience today?' They have a happy face or a sad face and you just hit as you go by depending on how it went.
"So that's the direction we are going, putting iPads in workplaces, devices on people's phones and not asking 140 questions but one or two questions and over time you can build up a picture," Williams says.
And it is no longer only your manager who will rate you but your colleagues and underlings too.
"It is much more flexible than a manager rating their staff, it is everyone rating everyone," Williams says.
For many employees this sounds like hell and Williams readily admits that no one has worked out the best way to process all the information.
"No one is there yet because most companies are still in transition," he says.
Chief executive of Vocus Communications, James Spenceley is a fan of this new "outside of the box" management style. His company's new head of human resources, Denise Hanlon, has a big job ahead following the company's planned acquisition of Amcom which will see an additional 350 people joining the tech company.
Move to a live rating system "We gave the job to Denise who said: 'I really hate your system of rating people. I think we throw that out and move to a live rating system, so people are peer-rated on a daily basis. We build an app for your iPhone and every time you interact with someone they can give you a thumbs up or thumbs down like Facebook. Is it that critical what your manager thinks of you compared to what value you are delivering to the business?'," Spenceley says.
However, there are those voicing their concerns about this new world order and say that while most of us don't like the annual review process, at least it provided some certainty.
"No annual performance review means a whole bunch of things including the business not being part of the development and journey of their staff," says principal at CoreData Andrew Inwood.
"The idea of immediate feedback for workers, without an annual plan of development, engagement, skills mapping and alignment with the issues facing the business and the marketplace reduces them to piece work.
"Here's what I want businesses to do: make a map for your people, review the work persistently, their progress quarterly and their goals annually. To do less is not to take the development of your staff seriously. People's careers matter, because their lives matter. As an employer you have a responsibility in that area," Inwood argues.
Inwood is not alone in his concerns.
Soon to be released research by PwC, which surveyed 100 organisations and 1000 employees in June, found dropping the review and ratings system could have big unintended consequences.
More than half (53 per cent) of employees' bonuses are determined based on individual performance and a majority of employees still find the year end performance review useful. Nearly two thirds (67 per cent) said performance reviews help them understand how they are doing, four in 10 said they motivate them and nearly half (48 per cent) said they help them progress and think about their career. Only just over a third (37 per cent) said they were a waste of time.
Something better than nothing Yes, the silent majority believe that something is better than nothing, and certainly better than some sort of constant social media feedback loop.
But the results are in and there is no turning back now. The PwC research reveals the dam has already broken: two thirds of large companies are making changes to their end-of-year performance reviews, with 5 per cent of organisations considering dropping performance ratings altogether.
Thorburn argues NAB will still have mechanisms in place to award bonuses.
"I think we've still got ways to do it," he says.
"We want to allocate bonuses against KPIs in the 162 performance units. There are balanced scorecards and we go through those every month. It's bringing real transparency and real accountability for people who are in those roles and therefore bonuses get allotted in a transparent, objective, fair way over the course of a year, and then some of that gets deferred," Thorburn says.
PwC's Williams warns that despite the current sense of euphoria, this time next year we may well be sorry for what we wished for.
"In a year people might suddenly go, 'hang on, we've lost something here', I am very nervous about that," he says.
